linkTarget.anchoringText: The Lost Hills field is located about 45 miles northwest of Bakersfield (Figure 1). The Lost Hills field was discovered in 1910 and hydraulic fracturing was introduced in late 1970s. Water flooding was introduced in 1992 and it has become the main production method. The main reservoir rock type is diatomite which is formed by the accumulation of diatoms, single cellular organisms. The average pay thickness is about 800 ft to 1,000 ft and the depth to the reservoir base is about 2,000 ft. The reservoir comprises three sub-rock types, siliceous diatomite, sandy diatomite, and clean diatomite based on its mineral contents.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Maps of Lost Hills and other San Joaquin Valley Fields.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maps of Lost Hills and other San Joaquin Valley Fields.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In simple explanation, what SVM does is to build a hyperplane or set of hyperplanes which separates data into separate groups (classification) or forms regression line (hyperplane is a subspace of one dimension less than its ambient space, i.e. a plane in 3D space). Figure 2 shows the example of classification in 2D space. The red line is a hyperplane and it is set to have the maximum gap between two classes. Data vectors in circles are border-line members and are called support vectors. When it is hard to build a hyperplane as shown in Figure 3, data is mapped into a higher dimensional space where a hyperplane is found. This mapping is done using a kernel function. Among various kernel functions, Gaussian function (radial basis function) was used in this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: SVM separates two separate groups by finding out a hyperplane (red line) so that the gap is maximized. Data vectors in circles are border line members and are called support vectors.

formatted-caption.caption-text: SVM separates two separate groups by finding out a hyperplane (red line) so that the gap is maximized. Data vectors in circles are border line members and are called support vectors.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In simple explanation, what SVM does is to build a hyperplane or set of hyperplanes which separates data into separate groups (classification) or forms regression line (hyperplane is a subspace of one dimension less than its ambient space, i.e. a plane in 3D space). Figure 2 shows the example of classification in 2D space. The red line is a hyperplane and it is set to have the maximum gap between two classes. Data vectors in circles are border-line members and are called support vectors. When it is hard to build a hyperplane as shown in Figure 3, data is mapped into a higher dimensional space where a hyperplane is found. This mapping is done using a kernel function. Among various kernel functions, Gaussian function (radial basis function) was used in this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: When there is no linear hyperplane, data points are mapped into a higher dimesion where a linear decision surface (hyperplane) exists. Mapping into a higher dimension is done using a kernel function (after Statnikov et al. 2009).

formatted-caption.caption-text: When there is no linear hyperplane, data points are mapped into a higher dimesion where a linear decision surface (hyperplane) exists. Mapping into a higher dimension is done using a kernel function (after Statnikov et al. 2009).

linkTarget.bib:
Statnikov et al. 2009
V. Statnikov , et al.2009, A Gentle Introduction to Support Vector Machines in Biomedicine AMIA Annual Symposium, San Francisco, CA 14 18November

linkTarget.anchoringText: Voronoi diagram is the division of space into regions around each point that are shaped so that the borders of the regions are equidistant from the two nearest points. In reservoir engineering application, these boundaries are the proxy of no-flow boundary (Figure 4). Especially, the reservoirs of which no flow boundaries are hard to estimate like Lost Hills, Voronoi diagram serves as approximated drainage areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: No flow boundary condition. Since the boundaries of a Voronoi cell is located at the same distances from points, it is a proxy of a no flow boundary.

formatted-caption.caption-text: No flow boundary condition. Since the boundaries of a Voronoi cell is located at the same distances from points, it is a proxy of a no flow boundary.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows the histograms of each attribute and its classes. The mean values of each class are compared in Table 1. All the numbers shown in the figure and table are normalized between 0 and 1 to remove the impact of different scales of input data on training. Two classes show clearly distinctive characteristics in that Class 1 producers are in better reservoir and have large hydraulic fractures. All distributions and means of Class 1 are higher than those of Class 0. Producers in superior reservoir quality area coupled with larger hydraulic fracture sizes tend to be better oil producers. Figure 6 shows distributions and means of the normalized first year oil production rates of each class.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Histograms of each input attributes. Histograms in blue are for Class 0 and histograms in orange are for Class 1. Class 1 producers were drill in good reservoir area and had bigger hydraulic fractures.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histograms of each input attributes. Histograms in blue are for Class 0 and histograms in orange are for Class 1. Class 1 producers were drill in good reservoir area and had bigger hydraulic fractures.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows the histograms of each attribute and its classes. The mean values of each class are compared in Table 1. All the numbers shown in the figure and table are normalized between 0 and 1 to remove the impact of different scales of input data on training. Two classes show clearly distinctive characteristics in that Class 1 producers are in better reservoir and have large hydraulic fractures. All distributions and means of Class 1 are higher than those of Class 0. Producers in superior reservoir quality area coupled with larger hydraulic fracture sizes tend to be better oil producers. Figure 6 shows distributions and means of the normalized first year oil production rates of each class.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Normalized first year oil production rate distributions. The normalized mean oil rate of Class 1 producers (0.37) is 1.76 times greater than that of Class 0 producers (0.21).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Normalized first year oil production rate distributions. The normalized mean oil rate of Class 1 producers (0.37) is 1.76 times greater than that of Class 0 producers (0.21).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 shows spatial distributions of producers in Lost Hills. Blue squares represent Class 0 producers and green circles are for Class 1 wells. The wells in the periphery of the reservoir tend to be in Class 0 and the inner producers are more to be in Class 1. It is well aligned with that the reservoir quality in the inner area is better than the outside of the reservoir in terms of oil saturation, porosity and sand thickness. Normalized first year oil production rates, proppant, reservoir quality, and slurry changes against hydraulic fracturing dates are shown in Figure 8. Since 2013, there are few Class 1 producers even though the reservoir quality (SoPhiH) does not change compared to the previous years. The main reason for this reduction is the result of smaller hydraulic fracturing job size. The average amount of proppant and slurry volume after 2013 is about a half of the previous years’. Initial production (IP) after 2013 decreased more than the nominal decline rate. Smaller hydraulic fracturing job size may be one of the reasons contributing such IP reduction.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Spatial distributions of Lost Hills producers. Blue squares and green circles represent Class 0 and 1 producers respectively. Class 1 producers are located inside of the reservoir where reservoir quality is better.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spatial distributions of Lost Hills producers. Blue squares and green circles represent Class 0 and 1 producers respectively. Class 1 producers are located inside of the reservoir where reservoir quality is better.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 shows spatial distributions of producers in Lost Hills. Blue squares represent Class 0 producers and green circles are for Class 1 wells. The wells in the periphery of the reservoir tend to be in Class 0 and the inner producers are more to be in Class 1. It is well aligned with that the reservoir quality in the inner area is better than the outside of the reservoir in terms of oil saturation, porosity and sand thickness. Normalized first year oil production rates, proppant, reservoir quality, and slurry changes against hydraulic fracturing dates are shown in Figure 8. Since 2013, there are few Class 1 producers even though the reservoir quality (SoPhiH) does not change compared to the previous years. The main reason for this reduction is the result of smaller hydraulic fracturing job size. The average amount of proppant and slurry volume after 2013 is about a half of the previous years’. Initial production (IP) after 2013 decreased more than the nominal decline rate. Smaller hydraulic fracturing job size may be one of the reasons contributing such IP reduction.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Changes of normalized 1 year oil rates, reservoir quality (SoPhiH), slurry, and proppant (clockwise from top left) against hydraulic fracturing dates. Blue dots and green dots represent Class 0 and 1, respectively.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Changes of normalized 1 year oil rates, reservoir quality (SoPhiH), slurry, and proppant (clockwise from top left) against hydraulic fracturing dates. Blue dots and green dots represent Class 0 and 1, respectively.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To investigate the impact of the completion, wells of which normalized SoPhiH is greater than 0.71 (mean of Class 1) were only selected so that wells drilled in superior reservoir quality area were only compared (Figure 9). By doing so, we can examine the impact of completion attributes on being better producers. Solid points are the producers passed the filter and points that are grayed out represent wells of which normalized SoPhiH is less than 0.71. As shown in the figure, spatial distributions of both classes are not distinctive. Regardless of its classes, wells passed the filter are located inside of the reservoir. However, two classes show quite differences in completion attributes (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Spatial distributions of Lost Hills producers after filtering wells in superior reservoir quality area. Points in solid are the wells in superior reservoir quality area and points that are grayed out represent wells do not pass the filter.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spatial distributions of Lost Hills producers after filtering wells in superior reservoir quality area. Points in solid are the wells in superior reservoir quality area and points that are grayed out represent wells do not pass the filter.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To investigate the impact of the completion, wells of which normalized SoPhiH is greater than 0.71 (mean of Class 1) were only selected so that wells drilled in superior reservoir quality area were only compared (Figure 9). By doing so, we can examine the impact of completion attributes on being better producers. Solid points are the producers passed the filter and points that are grayed out represent wells of which normalized SoPhiH is less than 0.71. As shown in the figure, spatial distributions of both classes are not distinctive. Regardless of its classes, wells passed the filter are located inside of the reservoir. However, two classes show quite differences in completion attributes (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Mean values of normalized oil rates, reservoir quality (SoPhiH), slurry, and proppant (clockwise from top left) of wells drilled in superior reservoir quality area. Even though the reservoir quality between two classes is almost identical, the mean oil rate of Class 1 wells is 1.85 times greater.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mean values of normalized oil rates, reservoir quality (SoPhiH), slurry, and proppant (clockwise from top left) of wells drilled in superior reservoir quality area. Even though the reservoir quality between two classes is almost identical, the mean oil rate of Class 1 wells is 1.85 times greater.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Testing set was not used for training but was used for testing how the trained model predicts well. Regularization parameters were determined using the grid searching method to prevent over-fitting. Training and testing accuracies are 0.997 and 0.987, respectively. To estimate the sensitivity of input attributes, impact factors were calculated using the method suggested by Yeten et. al. (2005). Pseudo pareto chart is shown in Figure 11. In the figure, it should be in mind that the magnitude of impact factors do not have any physical meaning. Impact factors only tell which attribute has relatively more impact on the model. As we observed from the K-means clustering analysis, completion attributes (proppant and slurry) are the top two highest impact attributes on the trained SVM model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Pseudo Pareto chart of the trained SVM model. Completion attributes (proppant and slurry) are the top two highest impact features.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pseudo Pareto chart of the trained SVM model. Completion attributes (proppant and slurry) are the top two highest impact features.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Set a criterion of COIP/area and filter out Voronoi cells passing the filter (Figure 12). If you need to develop only high oil saturated area, then you need to set a relatively high value. Or, if you need to build more drilling queues, then set a lower value. In this study, we set up 0.71 of normalized COIP/area which is the mean of Class 1 wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Voronoi cells filtered by normalized COIP/area of 0.71 (mean of Class 1 producers). Dark green dots are active producers (seeds of Voronoi cells) and white Voronoi cells are the ones filtered out. Cell color represents the value of the normalized COIP/area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Voronoi cells filtered by normalized COIP/area of 0.71 (mean of Class 1 producers). Dark green dots are active producers (seeds of Voronoi cells) and white Voronoi cells are the ones filtered out. Cell color represents the value of the normalized COIP/area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Select Voronoi cells which have not been drained effectively. Well counts of Class 1 producers including not-active wells in such cells are small (Figure 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: The historic well counts of Class 1 producers per cell. The Class1 well count is the total number of producers which are classified as Class 1 producers including abandoned wells. Well counts of white Voronoi cells are not calculated.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The historic well counts of Class 1 producers per cell. The Class1 well count is the total number of producers which are classified as Class 1 producers including abandoned wells. Well counts of white Voronoi cells are not calculated.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Select locations near Voronoi boundaries (near the area not drained much) but far enough from abandoned and active producers and from the injector lines to prevent early water breakthrough (Figure 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Selecting infill well locations. Red circles are the locations of the selected new infill wells. New locations should avoid being aligned nearby injector lines (blue lines).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Selecting infill well locations. Red circles are the locations of the selected new infill wells. New locations should avoid being aligned nearby injector lines (blue lines).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Generate the new Voronoi diagram to re-calculate COIP/area (Figure 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: After adding new infill well locations (red dots), new Voronoi diagram is generated and the potential of each new wells are evaluated using the SVM model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: After adding new infill well locations (red dots), new Voronoi diagram is generated and the potential of each new wells are evaluated using the SVM model.
